participants.participant: Mariel von Drathen, Head of Investor Relations
Peter Löscher, President and Chief Executive Officer of Siemens AG
Joe Kaeser, Head of Corporate Finance and Controlling
Barbara Kux, Head of Supply Chain Management

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Good morning and good afternoon to those watching our webcast. I'm Mariel von Drathen, Head of Investor Relations, and it is my pleasure to welcome you this afternoon to our Second Quarter 2009 Results.

The earnings release, the flashlight, and other documents were published this morning at 7:30, and they can be downloaded from our IR webpage. This afternoon's presentation is available on our website and is being webcast.

I would also refer to the Safe Harbor statement on Slide #2. Our President and CEO Peter Löscher and our Chief Financial Officer, Joe Kaeser are here this afternoon to present Q2 results. They are joined by Barbara Kux, Member of the Managing Board, who will review the supply chain initiative with you. After the presentation, we will have time for Q&A where Joe, Barbara, and Peter will answer your questions.
So with that, I would like to hand it over to Peter.

Thank you, Mariel. Good afternoon to everybody. Welcome to everybody around the world. I will quickly start with providing you with the highlights of the quarter, and Joe will then give you a detailed update on the financials as well as the SG&A program. And Barbara will then reveal her long-awaited supply chain initiative and the key elements of it.

Let me start giving you some of the highlights. I said this morning at the press conference, the crisis has arrived at Siemens, but Siemens is not in the crisis. I think we are handling, particularly relative to the performance of a number of our competitors, the crisis at this point in time better. We have also improved significantly since we have announced to all of you the TAP program roughly 18 months ago.

We have focused our portfolio. I think we now see the strength of the three sector organizations in terms of having the balance between short-cycle and long-cycle business. We have proactively sharpened our portfolio approach. In this quarter, the most recent example is we have completed the sale of our stake in Fujitsu Siemens Computers, which is just one of example of our proactive approach towards it.

We have also streamlined and empowered new management teams. We have set rigorous performance goal. And I'm very pleased to share with you today that we are making an extremely good progress on our announced SG&A program. The SG&A expenses are significantly lower compared to prior quarter.

So we have moved with an increased transparency with accountability and also with having now two clean quarters with performance. But there is no doubt that the challenges are real and the current economic crisis has also an impact on our portfolio particularly in the short cycle businesses in industrial, like Industry Automation, Drive Technology and like Osram. I will cover them in a minute.

Overall our results show strong relative performance in the quarter with an excellent contribution from the Energy sector. And I think quite an impressive performance from the Healthcare sector, bearing in mind that the current economic environment for the Healthcare sector in the United States is as challenging as it probably has been for a long time.

Our balance sheet remains one of the best in this sector. We have remained our high investment grade credit rating. We continue to focus on lowering our cost base and increasing our flexibility. We have already aligned our German workforce to the new demand levels, and we are particularly rapidly deploying the short work week concept in our German factories. We are increasing the immediate fixed cost flexibility, while we also allow our skilled workforce to be ready when the economy will recover.

The SG&A program with a run rate of €1 billion has already delivered concrete results in the second quarter, and it's fully on track to meet our targets for 2010. And I particularly believe that in today's environment there is nothing wrong with overachieving some of our targets, and we definitely expect this for the SG&A program.

Let me quickly run through some of the financial highlights of the quarter. Our backlog is at an impressive level and continues to grow with no material cancellations and a few push-outs, which validates our conservative booking process. Our book-to-bill in the second quarter remained at 1.1 robust, which is impressive given the economic backdrop. And back of our backlog, revenue growth was 5% and total sector profit was with 1.844 billion, quite a good achievement.

Orders tracked largely as we expected, sequentially down 6% compared with Q1. Of particular note was the excellent order development in mobility, where we have booked this quarter a major order in China for components of 100 high-speed trains, and renewables, where we also booked three very important customer orders.
Cash flow at the sector level was at 1.9 billion in the quarter, essentially flat from last year but significantly higher than Q1, and as a result of continued strict networking capital management.
Excellent execution against the backlog growth revenue performance in the quarter, and this despite the headwinds which the different sectors are facing right now.

From a geographic perspective, in emerging markets like China and Brazil, which the Management Board has visited last week, Siemens is exceptionally positioned and received more orders than in the second quarter of last year. I have already mentioned the major order what we have received in transportation.

And as I already mentioned we had significant order wins in Renewables and Mobility, and as expected these wins were more than offset by market fall in orders in Industry Automation, Drive Technology, and Osram. The remaining divisions in Industry and Energy sectors also had weaker order intake. For the Healthcare, organic growth in orders and revenue, as I mentioned, was impressive given the challenging Healthcare environment what we see in the United States.

It's important to highlight that our backlog on the left-hand side, as you can see, has increased by 2 billion and stands now at the record level of 87 billion, which gives us good visibility as we go into the second half of the year and beyond. We expect roughly 23 billion of our backlog to be converted into revenue in the second half of fiscal '09, and overall the energy sector accounts for the lion's share of this backlog, accounting for about 48 billion. The Mobility division and to a lesser extent Industry Solutions accounts for a backlog of 32 billion within the Industry sector.

The solid foundation provided by our backlog is further strengthened by the growing installed customer base across Siemens. It's worth noting that some 20% of the world's installed power generation fleet carries a Siemens label, and this drives the Energy sector's growing service business, our increase in service revenues improving our resiliency in a downturn. And this is further supported by our recurring revenue businesses such as the Industry sector, PLM software businesses, or the Healthcare sector's, IT business.

Let's now take a look at the performance at the sector-by-sector level. Starting with Industry, as expected overall revenues were down 6% with new orders down 12. The market continues to be weak, and the channel has continued destocking. This has put sector margins under pressure in Q2. As I mentioned before, we took early and decisive action at the Industry Automation, Drive Technology, and Osram. Even the inventories are down as production levels have been reduced.

We have reduced discretionary spending and we have increased labor flexibility in Germany and, as I mentioned before, we have particularly expanded the short time work week. We are currently standing at 12,000 employees in Germany, going to roughly 19 by June this year. The particular focus is on the Industry segment. So if you compare as a base phase where the majority is actually the production environment in Industry, the 12 compares to roughly 25% of our industrial labor force in Industry going to almost 40% by end of Q3.

As you know, Osram is restructuring, and you will see those charges in the third and fourth quarters. In Building Technologies, revenue remained largely stable, but orders softened as anticipated given the slowdown in commercial construction, which will impact revenue in later quarters. Industry Solution is seeing the effect of weakening metals market in its orders, but the revenue still remains stable.

Mobility is on track, actually ahead of track, with continued strong execution in the quarter. The order book and the backlog have never been better in this division. Recently, we have also completed our second review in terms of looking into the broader quality of this business, and we are extremely happy to report the margin perspective of this business has improved significantly versus a year ago.

Moving to the Energy sector, where performance was very strong, the book-to-bill remained robust in the quarter at 1.3. Strong execution helped revenues to increase at 28% year-on-year, and all divisions remained in the target ranges with all project issues fully resolved what we have shared with you last year. As a result, the underlying margin increased to 12.9% in the quarter.

New orders were lower, but this is set against the record quarter in the prior year, making particularly the comparable for this quarter challenging. It is again worth noting that at the end of the quarter, the Energy sector's backlog increased to 48 billion. Again we have no material order cancellations. The Energy sector also booked a significant order in the quarter from Iraq for power generation and transmission worth approximately €1.5 billion.

Renewables continues to see high activity levels with revenue increasing by 88%. They won two major long-term high-margin orders in the quarter. In Denmark we won a very significant order with DONG Energy to supply 500 offshore turbines with 1,800 megawatts. And in England, we secured a major contract for the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm from StatoilHydro and Statkraft to provide 88 wind turbines, 350 megawatt with a contract volume of more than €450 million. As a result, total order growth was 75% year-on-year, and margins increased to 13.1%. The Oil and Gas division increased profits to 121 million in the quarter, although the pace of new orders slowed.

Turning to Power Transmission, revenue solidly increased in the quarter by 21% to €168 million, while new orders fell by 19% and Power Distribution's performance mirrored Transmission for the quarter. Revenue rose by 23% to 106 million with a margin of 12.5%.

And finally turning to Healthcare, the overall situation continues to evolve. While Healthcare demand remains a constant, the funding situation particularly in the United States is under increased pressure. And in this environment our Healthcare sector performed solidly with a 4% increase in revenues.

Global equipment sales eased slightly, but our Imaging & IT business delivered a strong performance relative to peers and throughout the overall sector performance in the quarter. It's for the first time that our Healthcare business is growth leader, volume leader, and margin leader in healthcare. We are the number one healthcare business for the first time in Q2, surpassing our major competitor of the United States. Although the U.S. equipment market continues to be weak, growth elsewhere helped us to offset this.

The Healthcare sector also continues to grow its high-margin service revenue streams. Additional resilience comes from the consumable business in diagnostics and IT software licenses, which helps to offset the challenges in the equipment market. In Diagnostics, orders and revenues were level with the prior year. Margins for the quarter were impacted mainly due to product launch costs, which will be launched in Q3.
Overall Healthcare's underlying margin fell in the quarter to 40%, driven by negative foreign exchange effects, although this was somewhat mitigated by the strong cost management focus.
That was a brief review of the quarter, and in a few moments I will come back with details on how we expect the rest of the year to unfold. And now over to you, Joe.

Yes, thank you very much, Peter. Very warm welcome also from my side to discuss the results and the valuation of our Q2 numbers. Let me first start with the key performance indicators for our Fit4 2010 program. With the upper left side, which is growth, you all know that we actually have committed to grow 2X GDP going forward, which probably needs some explanations on how we will be intending to achieve that with pluses and negative. So our commitment is that we will only have to suffer from half of the deterioration of the global GDP. So that's the translation in times when GDP is negative. And that, ladies and gentlemen, we believe is quite a challenge because of this cyclicity and the nature of our businesses.

Profitability for the sectors shows that Energy has been solidly – was in the target margins of 11 to 15%. We would not expect this one to deteriorate in the foreseeable future. Healthcare, we believe provided a solid profitability given the environment we see, particularly in some regions. And if we compare the underlying margin of Healthcare, which obviously excludes the PPA impact, then we are at 14%, which is the lower end also of the target margin. Industry certainly will continue to have its challenges in profitability, and I think we all agree that we have not seen the bottom in that particular sector.

On our cash conversion, we believe the organization has done a decent job in fiscal Q2. There was something to catch up for out of Q1. And you remember we said that we would not be particularly satisfied with the Q1 performance on asset management, that has changed. And I'll come to later in my presentation.

The cash conversion rate of 1.19 is a solid cash conversion given the fact that we also still have a significant number of cash outflow from the charges we have been taking during fiscal 2008. And the fact that the cash conversion rate deteriorates from 2.87 to 1.19 is obviously due to the fact that we had a significant number of charges in Q2 2008, which at that time were non-cash item and will lead to cash out over the following quarters.

Now in the capital efficiency, which is ROCE, in our case we significantly increased the ROCE numbers predominantly through the growth in profits across most of the divisions. And that one also we believe will go up also in the next couple of quarters.

Now let me come to the third part of our key performance indicators from the Fit4 2010 indicators, and that basically is the capital structure. Capital structure we defined as net debt over EBITDA. And we did adjust the net debt number to our so-called adjusted industrial net debt. And I'll come to that in a minute. This one we basically and, I have to admit, unintentionally overachieved with 1.12, and I quickly show you the reason how come.

If you just follow me now in the third column from the left, you see the 14.2 billion. That's our reported net debt in Q1 2009, and that number of 14.2 basically increased by 700 million in Q2 to 14.9. And that's the column, fifth one, the sixth one from the right, of 14.9. So the permanent impacts from that development, you see, came from key financing activities mostly through the dividend payment of 1.4 billion, and also of course currency impact stemming from the fact that, as you know, we also do have very, a significant amount of U.S. dollar- based bonds out in the market.

If you now translate the 14.9 reported net debt from Q2 into the so-called industrial adjusted net debt, then you see that obviously a major impact has come from the underfunding of the pension plan, which is 5.3 on the deficit and 0.6 negative on the OPEB, and then some other minor topics and of course also to adjust the Siemens Financial Services net debt to financial standards. So basically what we do here is we follow the formula rating agencies are also applying. And so we arrive at 10.6 billion adjusted industrial net debt, and that translates to 1.12 net debt over EBITDA.

Obviously it's pretty hard to tell how the pension funding will develop over time due to the volatility in the equity market. We believe we have done the right things, especially due to the fact that we also have replaced the majority of government bonds in favor of A-rated bonds from corporations. So we believe that this is the right thing going forward.

To give you maybe some more light on the pension deficit and how that transforms, this is the next page what you see here. We have some information here on assets that are DBO. You also see that the discount rate has come down significantly compared to 2008, and it's been going up a little bit as regard to Q2. So I think the slide itself is a self-explanatory. And it remains to be seen whether the low point of equity in March will recover sustainably going forward.

Now let me maybe come to the next one and that's cash conversion. We did significantly improve our quarter-on-quarter performance in free cash flow. And we also would expect cash inflow to continue not necessarily in Q3, which is usually a somewhat difficult quarter. But we also will see cash inflow coming from outside free cash flow items, for example, from the sale of real estate, as well as the proceeds from our divestiture from Siemens Fujitsu, which has closed April 1, 2009.

Major differences between the reported income from continued operations on the right-hand side of the slide as compared to free cash flow in Q2 2009 obviously are the CapEx, which are 654 million, the amortization depreciation of plus 709. And the networking capital still accounts for about 165 million as a comparison to the reported income.

Now, ladies and gentlemen, I do know that there have been time and again some concerns on how companies will be doing in terms of liquidity. You can be rest assured we have a very clear focus on cash and liquidity. You'll see we have about 11.2 billion free liquidity. We have a very strong cash position at 7.7 billion, about €6.5 billion, which translates to about $8 billion, on undrawn credit facility at what I believe are attractive merchants. So there is headroom here in order to cover whatever comes as negative and as adverse impacts going forward.

One element to achieve cash focus and of course also liquidity are two items. First is a very stringent management of the CapEx, and you know that for many, many quarters now we have put a special emphasis on that topic. And the other one obviously is also how to manage a networking capital in an efficient manner.

On the working capital turns, we had some setback in fiscal Q1, which was not exactly satisfactory. We've been changing course again. We improved our networking capital turns from 7.8 to 8.2 quarter-on-quarter, and that was predominantly queued to the accounts receivables. And accounts receivables, as you know, have gone up for quite a period of time. We've put a lot of emphasis on managing those accounts receivables in both ways – bring the outstanding number down, and secondly also make sure that the quality in terms of overdues remain intact and make sure that we collect the money as we have invoiced. There is still way to go in the inventory piece where we cannot yet be satisfied with the development of the turns, and that certainly will be a particularly focus going forward.

On the CapEx spending, I think the right-hand side on the slide pretty much shows on how tightly we have been managing CapEx. We mentioned earlier that we have basically released about 50% of the budget. And with our performance here, you'll see that currently we are about just 88% CapEx of depreciation. So the current forecast will probably get us in the neighborhood of the lower end of our target margins, which we has installed between 95 and 150%. So tight capital is definitely something we have a very clear focus on. And if you compare the order growth with the CapEX rate, you clearly see how quickly the company has been acting on those matters.

Now obviously I do realize that there has been a lot of questions and sometimes even concerns about Treasury Siemens Financial Services in light of the financial crisis and, let's say, other enterprises' deterioration of profitability in those aspects. Here is a description on how we manage money in Siemens in Treasury, and I'll come to in a little while.

First of all the Treasury management in Siemens is very successful. We have actually managed to have a profit of 125 million in fiscal Q2 2009. Treasury in Siemens is predominantly risk-based, but obviously also increasingly a P&L-driven aspect. You see here how we manage bonds, how we do the financial business, and how we also manage the operating Treasury business. Those are the key terms and the fundamental rules on how Siemens manages Treasury. I think it's pretty much self-explanatory. So if there are any questions, I'd be happy to go into more detail.

But I would rather now prefer to continue on to Siemens Financial Services, which is on the next page. On the upper left you see that, as I said, contrary to many other very, very well. We are at record quarters. That's true for IBIT as well as for return on equity. Not suggesting that the 39.8% of return on equity or the 117 IBIT is, let's say, the starting point for further forecast. That certainly had also a couple of favorable items in it. But the key message here, ladies and gentlemen, we do have a stable business.

So why is that? Basically it's the case because Siemens Financial Services has to follow very, very strict rules on how that division is doing business, and a subset of those rules is now displayed here on the lower left of the slide. First of all, SFS continues on areas where we do have the main know how. The main know how means that we do have know-how in those industrial sectors Siemens is also doing business in like energy, like industry, and of course to a material extent in healthcare. And that's what SFS is going to focus on. This is our home turf. This is where we understand the business and where we do understand the value of quality of our customers. We do when/run the financing, and we do have the ability to make very deliberate make-or-buy decisions, and we do it in our own balance sheet.

The only you hold to maturity investing. There is no credit rating. There is no – no – loan maturity mismatch, not a single one. That's a very iron rule and very, very keen on focusing on. And we are obviously not invested in neither real estate nor subprime mortgage nor consumer lending, and certainly not in structured credit products. The right-hand side on the slide gives you an overview on what the exposure is by product and also on how we have invested and put our money to work by country.

So we have SFS, and I will make that very clear again. We do have SFS to provide financial know-how, provide financial platforms, provide domain competency on financial management, and also of course provide economical scale for Treasury, as well as for Financial Services to support the industrial business of the company.

That much to Treasury and Siemens Financial Services, let me now give you an update on how we are doing on our SG&A program, which is the next slide. As you have heard already from Peter, the good news is we've made very good progress – very good progress – already in Q2. And best probably is that it all just shows in the numbers in the P&L. if you look at our financial statements, which we have distributed this morning together with the earnings release, you'll see that the Q2 numbers of SG&A came down from 3.243 billion in 2008 to 2.520 in 2009. And the year-to-date number has been come down from 6.3 billion year-to-date 2008 to 5.4 billion in 2009. So it works, it shows, and we continue to have our focus on SG&A.

Maybe the not-so-good news is that it would be a little premature to just multiply the 5.4 billion by two and then arrive at a number, which would be considered a forecast for 2009, reason being that there are a few favorable one-offs in the Q2 numbers, which may not return again in Q3 and Q4. But it can be rest assured that the direction remains in place. And as Peter already said, there is nothing wrong with exceeding margins. There's certainly a lot wrong in not meeting the targets at all.

So that much to the SG&A. If we want to take a closer look into, let's say, the key drivers on those topics, you'll see that in terms of the consultancy cost. And please mind the footnote here. It's important in terms of how it splits between SG&A-related consultancy cost and cost of goods sold.

So we've come over a 600-million starting point over 217 in 2008. We arrived at 210 million consulting cost in the first half, and those 210 are supposed to arrive at 380 for the course of fiscal year 2008. IT costs also have come down from 1.3 billion in 2007, 2008 run rate, now down at 500. And here I think it's fair to just multiply them by two to arrive at the ballpark number for IT of about a billion for the fiscal year 2009.

Now complexity drivers such as legal entities and number of reporting units you'll see, we working our way through here. They may not necessarily drive down the cost directly, but they certainly are an enabler to get complicity out of the system and make sure that we identify additional potential for G&A savings as we go along.

While we have not materially reduced the workforce in production in the reported head count numbers nor in R&D because we still do believe innovation is a key element for sustainable competitiveness going forward, the SG&A number of head count has come down 9% in marketing and selling, and 12% in G&A. So you can see it also was there. I still want to make sure this is a cost-efficiency program, not necessarily a head count reduction program, but the improvement of our competitiveness initiative shows in all the different aspects of cost efficiency.

Now if we have look at the sector achievements so far, you can see that we are very much on track in the three big sectors. The corporation and other operation performance, I think this has to reasonably well. And it's not going to go back, so this is an achieved level.

And here you can clearly see that the cleanup of the other operation had a significant positive impact also in SG&A. So we're working our way through, and we continue to be very close to the numbers and make sure that we make good on our promises as the SG&A is concerned.

There is some delay on the so-called cost sector divisions, which is predominantly SIS, reason being that SIS had to benchmark itself and its IT deliveries into the sectors. And this has been achieved now. The IT costs, as you have seen also in the IT cost slide here, have been lower by 20%. So SIS needs to make sure that it works at benchmark levels also to support the sectors. And now the next goal will be to catch up in the SG&A area.

So that much, ladies and gentlemen, to the update on later drivers of SG&A and also on financials, predominantly liquidity and debt. So that concludes my presentation, and I hand it over to Barbara. Thank you very much.

Thanks, Joe. And a very warm welcome to all of you. As many of you may know, I've spent many years in the supply chain area. It's really an exciting place to be, and from what I have read recently it appears that you are as excited as I am.

Since joining Siemens, I visited many sites and many suppliers to develop plans to make Siemens a world leader in supply chain management. There is a tremendous energy in the company around this topic and the opportunity we have. We are aiming to deliver solid results to Siemens performance, both in the short term and sustainably going forward.

Today I will tell you how far we have come and where we are focusing our activities. Let's start with some facts. Siemens is one of the largest industrial purchasers in the world. In fiscal 2008, Siemens purchased materials, services, and finished goods worth about 50% of our total revenue. This corresponds to a total external spend of about 40 billion last year.

The savings opportunities for Siemens broadly reflect the split in external spend. 53% of spend is direct material at the sector level, with the remainder split between pooled direct material and indirect material spend. These are big numbers. And reducing material costs is obviously a significant part of the supply chain initiative.

It is also equally important to manage supply risks during the downturn. Now is the perfect time for Siemens to optimize its supply chain. Raw material costs are down. Suppliers with spare capacity are listening a lot more intently to us. At the same time the value of Siemens as a partner has never been higher. We have the brand, the scale, and the stability that suppliers want.

So what we are driving towards is a structural change in supply chain management within Siemens, not just a short-term initiative. The initial phase is to optimize our supply base. Then we will focus on our strategic suppliers, those who combine competitive pricing with excellent quality and ongoing innovation. If executed well, this will improve Siemens' performance permanently with a significant financial impact.

In short, this is a game-changing effort. Our targets are ambitious. The savings potential is real. We will be world-class. We are in an active dialogue with our customers and suppliers today. And Siemens will be at world-class levels at the end of 2010.

We hit the ground running in January and the pace is accelerating. The structure, responsibilities, and targets for the supply chain initiative are embraced at the sector level, in the divisions and regions. The whole company is fully engaged. In just three month, we've achieved a lot. We've renegotiated terms and pricing with about 1,000 of our suppliers. We've already reviewed and redesigned our approach to indirect spend. We've already increased pooled spending – that's the dollar spend or the euro spend – at the total Siemens level.
In addition, we've held over 30 workshops with more than 300 suppliers and reviewed the relevant categories for spend, ranging from temporary labor to iron costing.

In total, more than 1,000 measures have been identified to further optimize our supply chain. No stone will go unturned. For example, one obvious area that will become increasingly important is the role of technology. Other measures include increased standardization and less complex specification or less over-engineered products.

There is also significant complexity in the large number of suppliers we have – over 100,000 to date. And optimizing the existing supplier base is the first step of our program. Many suppliers are only used on an occasional basis, adding costs and limiting the potential for cross-sector purchasing. In essence it's all about bundling, leveraging the buying power of Siemens, and concentration – focusing on those select suppliers who add the most value and deliver the optimum total cost of ownership to Siemens.

We have made good progress so far and are on track with all our short-term initiatives. The longer-term strategic roadmap is progressing well, and we will update you on this as things develop. Going forward, we have defined clear metrics to measure the impact of the program.

As I mentioned earlier, leveraging the purchasing power across the sectors is a key lever to increase cost savings. Today just 29% of total purchasing volume is managed at the Siemens level. Our target is to increase our pooled volume by 60% in 2010. This means about €19 billion of spend will be driven through cross-sector purchasing by the end of next year. One of the key differentiators of our program is global value sourcing. This goes way beyond basic pricing and low-cost country sourcing, but includes co-development and product innovation with our key suppliers. Our target here is to increase our share of global value sourcing from 20% in 2008 to at least 25% mid-term.

Global value sourcing is about creating long-term strategic value for Siemens, so developing the most competitive network of suppliers. This will enable us to leverage technology from our suppliers and to accelerate innovation at the right price. Our goal is clear. We will establish Siemens as a global leader in supply chain management. Our supplier reduction program will prepare the way for this. In the mid-term, we are planning to cut the number of suppliers from over 100,000 by 20%.

In summary, we will substantially increase the value that supply chain management delivers to Siemens. It is obvious that I love supply chain management. It is exciting, it is real-world, and it delivers. I look forward to updating all of you on our progress, the deliverables we achieve, and how it is impacting our overall performance.
And now let me hand back to Peter.

Thank you, Barbara. Let me sum up, and how do we manage and plan for the remainder of 2009. Our second quarter performance showed the underlying strength of our Siemens businesses. Our shorter-cycle businesses have felt the economic slowdown most acutely, and other divisions will feel these effects in quarters to come. Other divisions which benefit from fundamentally longer-cycle trends like Transportation, Energy, and Healthcare are doing relatively well.

We as a leadership team are intensely focus on improving the operational efficiencies across Siemens. We have improved our conversion into profit and cash flow from the last quarter, Q1. As Joe has shown, we have a powerful balance sheet and a conservative financing structure. Siemens is ready and prepared to deliver solid performance also in this very tough times.

As I said in my opening remarks, the global economy is probably experiencing one of the most turbulent periods it has seen in the decades. The current macro and financing environment show no signs of near-term improvement, and it's our view that we are still some way off from a real economic recovery.

I know you are all very familiar with the various macroeconomic indicators, but let me make two observations that are pertinent to Siemens. First, the world has changed since July 2008, when we have set our guidance. Then the GDP forecast for 2009 was plus 2.9%. Today we're talking about minus 5%, and no one could have imagined over nine months a 5-percentage point decline in global GDP forecasts. And the vast majority of our indicators remain negative, implying a continued contraction in the real economy for some time to come.

Today out of Germany we have received the latest forecast by the government, being planned for minus 6% for 2009. If we look at the VDMA data, the Machine Tool Manufacturers Association's data for Germany, which is a critical data point for Siemens, you can see that orders fell 49% year-on-year in February. And this was after a 40% fall in January. The latest number for March are pointing towards 39%. This survey covers the middelstand, our core customer base in Germany and correlates with what we have experienced in the quarter.

It's in this context that I'd like to now to turn outlook for Siemens for the year of 2009. When we have set our 2009 guidance last summer, the environment then looked dramatically different to the one we are facing today. Indeed some of you thought actually at that time Siemens is going for a very conservative number. But we have performed well overall in the first half of the year, arguably better than a number of our competitors, and fought hard for every dollar out there.

We are also very realistic about what is ahead of us. And as you know, the indicators what are still currently in front of us are indicating that we have not yet seen the bottom of the global economy. We have therefore decided to share with you that every year – every quarter we would continuously review our assumptions which are underlying our plans.

For this reason we have decided against the backdrop of the current economic environment to deliver a sector profit exceeding our last year number of 6.6 billion. And I can assure you that the Siemens organization and their totally leadership is fully committed to achieve this.

For the second half of the year, we expect the Industry sector, with the exception of Mobility, to continue facing headwinds from the slowdown. The Healthcare sector despite a very challenging U.S. market environment will continue to drive an overall solid performance, as we saw in the last two quarters. And finally, the Energy sector will continue to drive strong revenue performance, although we continue to expect a slowdown in product orders and further customer deferrals through the second half of the year.

We are driving the business hard. We have a key strategy and a relentless focus on optimizing the business and reducing our cost base. You can clearly see what we are making progress.
